abstract: United States-China Business Council, group that lobbies on behalf of about 220 large American companies with operations in China, issues report taking direct aim at China's aggressive application of antimonopoly law and highlighting ways enforcement can be improved; move is apparent push back on China's antitrust clampdown on companies like Microsoft, Qualcomm and others.

headline.main: Western Companies Appear to Push Back Against Chinese Crackdown
headline.print_headline: Western Companies Appear to Push Back Against Chinese Crackdown

snippet: China’s Communist Party has devoted enormous resources to composing historical narratives, like that of the Fragrant Concubine, that seek to legitimize its rule.
lead_paragraph: China’s Communist Party has devoted enormous resources to composing historical narratives, like that of the Fragrant Concubine, that seek to legitimize its rule.
abstract: China's Communist Party has devoted enormous resources to composing historical narratives that legitimize its rule and obfuscate its failures; party-run history machines is especially single-minded in its effort to promote story lines that portray ethnic minorities like Uighurs as contented.

snippet: Researching a Canadian company that mines in China resulted in a Chinese-born Canadian citizen being arrested, terrorized and prohibited from leaving China.
lead_paragraph: Researching a Canadian company that mines in China resulted in a Chinese-born Canadian citizen being arrested, terrorized and prohibited from leaving China.
abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column relates story of Kun Huang, Chinese-born Canadian citizen who was arrested, terrorized and prohibited from leaving China for two years after he uncovered fraud at mining company Silvercorp Metals; contends that case shows how China has shown more hostility towards those who uncover frauds than to those who commit them.

headline.main: In China, Detecting Fraud Riskier Than Doing It

snippet: The nation, facing severe pollution from coal and a rising dependence on energy imports, has had limited success in extracting natural gas from coal and shale.
lead_paragraph: The nation, facing severe pollution from coal and a rising dependence on energy imports, has had limited success in extracting natural gas from coal and shale.
abstract: China has had only limited success as it pushes to increase domestic natural gas production and reduce rising dependence on energy imports; extraction process faces far more obstacles than in the United States, as workers struggle to avoid underground labyrinths of coal mines and clay-rich soil that impedes hydraulic fracturing.

headline.main: Natural Gas Production Falls Short in China
headline.print_headline: No Easy Path to Natural Gas

snippet: China’s legislature laid down strict limits to proposed voting reforms in Hong Kong, drawing battle lines in what could be a deepening confrontation over the future of the city and of China.
lead_paragraph: China’s legislature laid down strict limits to proposed voting reforms in Hong Kong, drawing battle lines in what could be a deepening confrontation over the future of the city and of China.
abstract: China's legislature tightens reins on Hong Kong politics by laying down strict limits to proposed voting reforms, choosing a showdown with a protest movement unlike any it has ever faced on the mainland; move closes one of few avenues left for gradual political liberalization in China after a sustained campaign against dissent under Pres Xi Jinping.

snippet: The sparse news treatment of the pope’s first visit to the Far East is indicative of the Chinese Communist Party’s continuing attempts to maintain a tight grip on Catholicism.
lead_paragraph: The sparse news treatment of the pope’s first visit to the Far East is indicative of the Chinese Communist Party’s continuing attempts to maintain a tight grip on Catholicism.
abstract: Broad news coverage of Pope Francis's first visit to East Asia, which began in South Korea, is conspicuously absent in China, where Communist Party is intent on maintaining tight grip on Catholicism, even as number of Chinese followers grows each year.

headline.main: For Chinese, Pope Seems Worlds Away in South Korea
headline.print_headline: For Chinese, Pope Seems Worlds Away in South Korea
